To T. [J.] CULLIFORD,Presumably Thomas John Culliford (1781-1852), CD’s maternal uncle; son of Thomas Culliford, musical instrument maker; partner in Dewar and Culliford, insurance brokers. [24 JANUARY 1837]

body.p: I regret to say that I cannot leave home this evening. Catherine is not so well as she was;Charley had been born on 6 Jan. and we have a consultation here, at six o’clock. I was seized last night with a violent pain in my head (fortunately, just as I had concluded my month’s work) and was immediately ordered as much medicine as would confine an ordinary-sized horse to his stall for a week. Whether it arises from the “Influentials”,I.e. influenza or from close application, or from worry, or from the wind cholic, to quote King Arthur,In Fielding’s The Great Tragedy of Tragedies; or, The Life and Death of Tom Thumb the Great, I, iii. I know not. But this I know – that sorely against my will and much to my disappointment, here I am, in a gloomy and miserable state, and here I must remain.

signed.persName: CHARLES DICKENS, T. C.Thus in MS. Culliford Esqre
